Introduction

Hyper-IgM syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency syndrome characterized by impaired immunoglobulin class switching.  Therefore, B cells continue to produce IgM, leading to decreased or absent serum IgG, IgA, or IgE.  Patients have recurrent infections and failure to thrive.

Pathogenesis



B-cell development begins in the bone marrow, where hematopoietic stem cells differentiate into immature B cells that migrate to peripheral lymphoid tissue (eg, spleen, lymph nodes) for maturation (

figure 1
).  Mature B cells are capable of producing IgM and IgD.  However, on exposure to antigens, mature B cells undergo a series of changes to become plasma cells, as follows:



  • In the absence of T-helper cells, most mature B cells differentiate into short-lived plasma cells that produce antigen-specific IgM.
  • In the presence of T-helper cells, most mature B cells differentiate into long-lived plasma cells that produce antigen-specific IgG, IgA, or IgE, as follows:
    • Immunoglobulin class switching:  This is the process by which mature B cells produce antigen-specific IgG, IgA, and IgE (
      ðŸ“Š View Table: video 1
      ).  Immunoglobulin class switching occurs in the germinal center and begins when CD40 ligand (CD40L) on CD4+ T-helper cells binds CD40 on mature B cells (
      figure 2
      ).  In response, T-helper cells secrete cytokines (eg, IL-4) that induce the expression of certain enzymes (eg, activation-induced cytidine deaminase [AID]) in mature B cells that are required for immunoglobulin class switching.
    • Somatic hypermutation:  Somatic hypermutation introduces random mutations in the variable region of the immunoglobulin gene, producing immunoglobulins with varying affinities for the target antigen.  Somatic hypermutation selects for mature B cells with the highest-affinity immunoglobulins.
    • Proliferation and differentiation:  Following immunoglobulin class switching and somatic hypermutation, most mature B cells differentiate into long-lived plasma cells that produce different classes of immunoglobulins.  Other mature B cells become memory B cells that immediately produce antigen-specific immunoglobulins on reexposure to the same antigen.


Hyper-IgM syndrome is characterized by impaired immunoglobulin class switching and therefore limited humoral responses to infections.  The most common cause of hyper-IgM syndrome is an X-linked recessive mutation in the gene that encodes CD40L.  Hyper-IgM syndrome can also occur due to other genetic mutations that impair the binding of CD40L and CD40, as well as intrinsic B-cell abnormalities (eg, genetic mutations in enzymes such as AID).  Rarely, hyper-IgM syndrome can occur secondary to certain conditions (eg, congenital rubella syndrome, T-cell malignancies).



CD40 is also expressed on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) (eg, macrophages, dendritic cells) (

figure 3
).  On binding CD40 on APCs, T-helper cells secrete cytokines (eg, tumor necrosis factor-alpha) that increase the expression of major histocompatibility complex class II, secretion of proinflammatory cytokines, and phagocytosis.  Together, these changes activate additional T-helper cells, which mount a potent cell-mediated immune response.  Therefore, although impaired humoral immunity is a feature of all forms of hyper-IgM syndrome, certain forms are also characterized by impaired cell-mediated immunity.



Overall, hyper-IgM syndrome is rare, and a family history of it is the most common risk factor.  In X-linked forms, male patients are most commonly affected, whereas female patients are asymptomatic carriers.

Clinical presentation



Hyper-IgM syndrome most commonly presents in infancy or early childhood with:



  • Sinopulmonary infections (eg, pneumonia, otitis media):  Occur due to deficient IgG, which is necessary for opsonizing encapsulated bacteria (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae) to allow recognition by phagocytes.
  • Gastrointestinal infections (eg, chronic diarrhea due to Giardia lamblia):  Occur due to IgA deficiency at the mucosal surface.
  • Opportunistic infections (eg, Pneumocystis, Cryptosporidium):  Occur due to deficient cell-mediated immunity.


Physical examination is often normal but may show minimal lymphoid tissue (eg, lymph nodes, tonsils) due to impaired germinal center formation.  Recurrent infections can lead to failure to thrive or poor weight gain (eg, increased metabolic demands, chronic diarrhea with nutrient loss).

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected hyper-IgM syndrome (eg, infant or young child with recurrent infections, failure to thrive, and minimal lymphoid tissue), initial laboratory evaluation includes:



  • Quantitative immunoglobulins:  Show markedly decreased or absent serum IgG, IgA, and IgE.  Because mature B cells continue to produce IgM, the serum IgM level is normal or elevated.  Of note, response to protein- and polysaccharide-based vaccines is impaired, and titers will be inappropriately decreased or absent following immunization.
  • Flow cytometry:  Shows normal numbers of total B and T cells, although the number of memory B cells is reduced.  Flow cytometry also shows impaired expression of CD40L on the surface of CD4+ lymphocytes following in vitro activation.
  • Complete blood count:  May show neutropenia, anemia, and/or thrombocytopenia.


Diagnosis requires confirmation with genetic testing, which can identify the exact genetic defect and guide genetic counseling.

Differential diagnosis



  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome:  This X-linked recessive disorder is characterized by combined immunodeficiency, similar to hyper-IgM syndrome.  However, this condition often presents in early infancy with microthrombocytopenia and excessive bleeding (eg, following circumcision, umbilical stump detachment) and eczema.
  • Bruton agammaglobulinemia:  This X-linked recessive disorder is characterized by decreased or absent B cells, IgM, IgG, and IgA.
  • Common variable immunodeficiency:  This condition is characterized by a normal number of B cells but decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA.
  • HIV/AIDS:  Perinatally acquired HIV/AIDS can present similarly to hyper-IgM syndrome with recurrent infections, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive in infancy or early childhood.  However, quantitative immunoglobulin levels are typically normal.  Leukopenia is expected, and the CD4/CD8 ratio would be low.

Management



Management of hyper-IgM syndrome involves:



  • Prophylactic antimicrobials (eg, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, fluconazole).
  • Broad-spectrum antimicrobials at the earliest sign of infection.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):  Provides passive immunity against common pathogens by pooling immunoglobulins from thousands of donors.  IVIG offers minimal protection from uncommon pathogens, leaving patients susceptible to infection.  In addition, IVIG cannot replace the immediate increase in immunoglobulin production on reexposure to a known antigen in immunocompetent patients.
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, which is curative and should be performed as soon as possible to avoid complications.

Prognosis



With prompt diagnosis and management, the prognosis for hyper-IgM syndrome is favorable.  In general, severe infection and liver/biliary tract disease (eg, due to opportunistic infectious agents such as Cryptosporidium) are associated with increased morbidity and mortality.  In addition, recurrent pulmonary infection can lead to bronchiectasis with significant morbidity and mortality.  Finally, similar to other forms of immunodeficiency, in hyper-IgM syndrome, patients are at increased risk for autoimmune conditions and malignancy, which are also associated with increased mortality.

Summary



Hyper-IgM syndrome (
